loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco A. is from the city of San Antonio, Ozamiz City. He is 59 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Francisco owns and operates a business providing tricycle transport services. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Francisco joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Francisco is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be his fourth from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his existing vehicle to provide better service

loans.name: Jalil

texts.ru: Мухудинов Чалил проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 39 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Чалил имеет среднее образование. Более 12 лет занимается изготовлением. Он плотник, изготавливает окна и двери. Кредит берет для закупа сырья, т.е. приобретение материала.
texts.en:
Jalil M. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 39 years old. He is married and has four children. His wife is a housewife. Jalil himself has a secondary education. He has worked as an artisan for more than twelve years. He is a carpenter, producing windows and doors. He is applying for credit in order to purchase materials for his business.

Translated from Russian by Irina Chakraborty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of materials

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en:
Bolormaa is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own apartment. Her two children, aged 18 and 13, are in secondary school.

Bolormaa operates a trading business at a local market called Narantuul. She operates a retail business and purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. Her product selection is very good and she has a great business mind.

Since Bolormaa started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and education for her sons. She is an open and very hardworking person.

Bolormaa is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Dominga's Group

texts.en:
Dominga C. is from the village of Tiaman, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old and is the group leader of this three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Dominga is married and has four adult children. She owns and operates a business making and selling food, preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Dominga joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
O. Robert is thirty-four years old and resides at Namrwothod Village in Nebbi town. He is a married man with six children and has two dependents; altogether, five are in school.

Robert owns O. Enterprises at Market Square, dealing in bicycle spare parts and repairs. He has been running the business for the last four years.

Robert is using the loan to purchase more bicycle spare parts, grease, and other lubricants. His future dream is to expand the business and, if possible, to open other branches.

loans.use: To purchase bicycle spare parts, grease, and other lubricants

texts.en:

C. Zainab owns a boutique (a shop selling clothes) located in Hawker market and she has been running the business for the last seven years. She is using the loan to purchase more clothes so as to add stock to her business.

C. Zainab is a promising businesswoman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her business

loans.name: Andeoye

texts.en:
D. R. Andeoye is a hardworking businesswoman, forty-two years old, who is married with seven children, all schooling. Three of them are in institutions, two in secondary schools, and two of them are in primary school.

D. owns a drugstore business located in Hawker market and she has been running the business for the last ten years. She is using the loan to purchase various drugs for her drugstore. She is a promising business woman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase various drugs for her drugstore

loans.name: Baigalmaa

texts.en:
Baigalmaa is 41 years old and lives with her sister and 6 daughters in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house, in a yard that belongs to her sister. Her husband, Naranbaatar, is currently working in Korea on a three-year labor contract. Her husband helped her with her business until he left to work overseas. 

She operates a shoe-trading business at Urt-tsagaan, the small outdoor market in Mongolia. She has been operating her business since 2003, and has steadily expanded her business since then. Since she founded her business, her living conditions have improved. She sells women and men shoes that she buys in Ereen, China, a border town, where many inexpensive Chinese products are imported to Mongolia. Because Baigalmaa chooses the cheapest shoes, her shoes are sold fast and easily. She is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: to increase working capital

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en:
A. Suzan is thirty-five years old, she is married and blessed with four children who are all studying in primary schools. A. Suzan owns a unique drug shop in Ociba Coast and she has been running the business for the last three years. 

She will use the loan to purchase a variety of drugs to sell to her clients. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to stock more drugs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase variety of drugs to sell to her clients.

loans.name: Uuganchimeg

texts.en:
Uuganchimeg T., age 39, lives with her family in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Currently, she lives in a house with her family and parents near Narantuul market which is close to her workplace.

Uuganchimeg has been selling Korean secondhand mattresses, bedding and linen since 2006. She is a modest, silent and responsible woman. She says, “When summer comes, tourist camps, resorts and hotels need bedding and linen so the sale of goods improves. I am thinking of saving revenue to repair my fence and build a house in Gachuurt Horoo, Bayanzurh district.”

Uuganchimeg is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more second hand goods at a wholesale price to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand goods to sell

loans.name: Zorumabel

texts.en:
Zorumabel O. is a 49-year-old woman whose passion is to grow her small sari-sari (variety) store business and its profits. “Sari-sari” is a tagalog (Philippine language) word which means a small volume of various grocery items, foodstuffs and beverages for retail.

Zorumabel wishes that, someday, her sari-sari store will turn to a mini-grocery store that has a larger volume of inventory to increase the number of her customers. With that, her profit would grow as well and she could put up a savings fund to support the medication of one of her children who has an ailment.

Also, Zorumabel wants to support the education of her youngest child until graduation from college. She may be unhappy for her eldest and second child who have not graduated from college yet. She understood that they are just victims of poverty.

Zorumabel promises to sustain her business through the loans she can request from ASHI because this is the only way she knows to combat poverty and improve the lifestyle of her family, rather than depending on the income generated by her husband who is a hired carpenter.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items, foodstuffs and beverages for her store

loans.name: Swad

texts.en:
Swad B. is a hardworking and very determined businesswoman. She is married to a businessman who is an active partner in the business and they have ten dependents.

Swad was initially financed by her husband and began to trade in foodstuffs and she is now selling household utensils which she has engaged in for eight years.

Swad is in need of a loan to buy more stock and she intends to use the additional proceeds from the loan to educate her children to university level and to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy more household utensils to sell

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata J. is a hardworking and very determined woman. She trades in used bags around the cotton tree area - along a busy street in the centre of Makeni City. She is married to a trader who is also an active partner in the business and they have five children.

Fatmata was financed by her husband when she began to trade in bags, which she has done for the past twenty years. She is in need of a loan that will enable her to buy more stock, thereby increasing her profit. She hopes to use the additional proceeds from the loan to educate her children and build a house in the near future.

loans.name: Amarbayasgalan

texts.en:
Amarbayasgalan is 50 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province in western Mongolia. Her family enjoys a comfortable lifestyle and have been living for twenty-five years at their current address. The family supports and helps Amarbayasgalan’s business.

Amarbayasgalan has operated her vegetable-trading business since 1995, both wholesale and retail. Now she has a stall in Hasuu market and aims to expand her business in the future. With her income, she has bought a car and electric appliances, but most important is that they have got a house. Now the family is building a house for her oldest son using her business revenues.

Amarbayasgalan is a hardworking, modest woman. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more vegetables and seed potatoes at a wholesale price.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables and seed potatoes to sell

texts.en:

Her husband operates taxi business. Her daugther, Oyun, is 16 years old and attends a local secondary school. Her son, Munkhjargal, is 2 years old.

Since Enkhtuya started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and paying her daughter's education fees. Recently, in 2010, Enkhtuya and her husband purchased a new car. She is an open and very hard-working person. She is requesting a loan to purchase current assets.

loans.use: to purchase current assets

He has made a living by running a mobile phone and spare parts business for the last three years and now has quite a few clients. Byambajav wishes to expand his business as well as open a mobile phone store and trading center. He is modest but confident and optimistic about achieving the goal. He is requesting a loan for 4,000,000 loan to buy mobile phones and spare parts from China.

Rodney C. lives in the village of Matugas Bajo, which is located in the part of the Philippines known as Misamis Occidental. He is 44 years old, married, has two school-aged children and makes a living by providing repair services to people who live in his community.

In 2009, Rodney joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business, and has already successfully repaid two previous loans from GDMPC. He used these loans to expand his small company, and is now applying for a new loan to buy supplies he needs to provide his services. He plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding his business.

loans.name: Suld

texts.en: Suld S. is 48 years old and lives with his wife in a traditional tent (known as a ger) in Zavhan province, western Mongolia. His wife helps him in his work, which consists of making jewelry from recycled materials such as plastic bottles and glass. He takes his output to Mongolia's capital, Ulaanbaatar, and sells his items there. Suld is a modest and hard-working person who very much wants to enlarge his business. He has applied for a loan for 1,000,000 MNT to increase his output by buying more raw materials.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making jewelry

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Being a mother, Anabel T.’s aspirations in life are all focused on the welfare of her children. Despite living in poverty, she is determined to achieve her goals no matter how hard she needs to work to make this happen. She will do this with her husband, who is always by her side and committed to accompany her through life.   

Today, Anabel's main goal is to build a home for her family and keep everyone safe from harm. She plans to pay for this home by raising pigs, and with help from her husband, who is an office worker. She joined ASHI in 2007 and has used several previous loans to establish her livestock business. She is now applying for a new loan to increase the number of piglets she can raise and sell for a profit.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Davaahuu

texts.en: Davaahuu M. is 55 years old and lives with his wife in a traditional Mongolian housing tent (known locally as a ger) in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. He graduated from a driving course in 1973, and has made a living providing transportation services for the last 18 years. He is very experienced in this line of work, and even transports coal in wintertime. He has applied for this loan to buy timber for resale, and eventually hopes buy a small car that he plans to operate as a taxi. Davaahuu is a modest, hard-working person and is very committed to improve the quality of his life.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: Thuy T. D. was born in 1965. She lives in Luong Quy village with her two daughters. She raises four hundred chickens and 20 pigs. Now, she copes with many difficulties because the price of food for poultry is expensive and her profits are low. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND). She has participaid in SEDA since 2005 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 2,834,000 VND to buy food for chicken and pigs.

loans.name: Lhagvajav

texts.en:
Lhagvajav S., age 54, lives with her husband, who is retired, and a son. She has been operating a meat trading business since 1998 and has gained much experience in this field. Her health is not good; she had a medical treatment last winter. Her husband ran the business while she was out. Her son is involved with inter provincial transportation. 

Lhagvajav is clever and creative. She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrik loan to purchase livestock from the sub-provinces.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian B., age 36, is from the village of Parog-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She and her husband have two school-aged children. To make a living, Lilian raises crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lilian has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lilian joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Lilian has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Lilian is now requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lilian from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small-business entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma B. is from the village of Mauswagon. She is 46 years old, married, and has 4 children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling corn from her own farm. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 2,300 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2004, Emma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Emma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer for the corn. This will be the 16th loan taken out by Emma from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for the corn

loans.name: Lovenia

texts.en: Lovenia Q. is from the village of Dinasan, Jose Dalman, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 57 years old, is married, and has four adult and one school-aged children. Lovenia operates a business selling cosmetics and another source of income for the family comes from her husband who is a farmer. Lovenia has been engaged in her business for ten years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. Now, Lovenia has joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

location.town: Dinasan, Jose Dalman, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Maribie

texts.en: Mrs. Maribie B. is from the barangay (village) of Purok Madasigon, Maningcol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old, is married, and has no dependents. Maribie is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store and a cellphone E-loading business. She’s been engaged in this kind business for two years already and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Maribie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting 20,000 PHP as her first loan, which will be used to add to the capital of her sari-sari store and E-loading business. Maribie plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments and possible business expansion. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store and E-loading businesses

location.town: P Makiangayon, Maningcol, Ozamiz City, Mindanao

loans.name: Leonarda

texts.en: Leonarda T. is from the village of Palaranan. She is 54 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Leonarda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Leonarda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her sari-sari store business. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia A. is from the village of Lumbayao. She is 60 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Emilia owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling coconuts in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month. In 1999, Emilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to redeem her pawned coconut land. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina N. is from the village of San Vicente. She is 29 years old and married with one small child. To make a living, Paulina provides transportation services to local community members. Paulina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Paulina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC and is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used for payment of her motor. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Paulina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: payment of her motor

loans.name: Burulkan's Group

texts.en:
Burulkan B. 49, is the leader of this group. She has two daughters, both of whom are married and live separately with their families. In order to make money Burulkan and her husband breed cattle to sell. They started this activity three years ago with an initial investment of 6000 soms ($130.26) with which Burulkan bought sheep to breed. She also sells milk, making 4600 soms ($100) per month. Now Burulkan wants to purchase bathrobes to resell. In the future she plans to repair the house and build a shed. 

Kunduzhon N. is 25. Her husband works as a taxi-driver. They have two small sons and a daughter that Kunduzhon cares for. She breeds cattle and cultivates different fruits and vegetables. She wants a loan to purchase a bull-calf for breeding. In the future Kunduzhon plans to increase the number of cattle and save money to purchase a new house in Bishkek.

Zhenishai K. 34, is the treasurer of the group. Her husband works at a sawmill. They have two sons and a daughter. Four years ago Zhenishai, with the initial investment of 5000 soms ($108.55), began to purchase clothes from the sewing workshop in order to resell them. In this way she makes 10000 soms ($217.1) per month. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase summer-season clothes to increase the turnover of her business. 

Tolkunai K. is 36. Her husband works as a welder. They have three sons; the older one goes to school and the others are still too small. Tolkunai takes orders and sews clothes at home. She started this activity three years ago with an initial investment of 2000 soms($53.42) and now she earns 5000 soms ($108.55) per month. With money from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and increase her turnover. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society); Planet (being environmentally friendly); and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team -- Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase summer-season clothes to resell

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie G. is from Gotokan Diot, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. and married to Efren G., a farmer. They have five children of whom two work, two are school age in their teens, and the youngest is elementary school age. To make a living, Josie sells firewood and snacks. She has done this for 10 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month. 

In 2007, Josie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie is now requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP, her 7th, to purchase fertilizers for her corn production and additional capital for her snack vending business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, savings for future use, loan repayments, her children’s education, and possible business expansions.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizer for corn production and additional capital for her snack vending business

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en:
Anastacia C. is from the village of San Isidro. She is 48 years old and married with five adult children. Anastacia sells crops from her farm which she has done for over four years earning approximately 8,000 PHP a month. She is also engaged in buying and selling copra.

In 2006, Anastacia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anastacia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,950 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase rice. Anastacia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for farming. This will be the tenth loan Anastacia has taken out from PMPC. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for farming

loans.name: Noory Group

texts.en: Khaleda is the group leader of the Noory group. She is married and lives in district 11, Kabul, Afghanistan. She has three children who are in school. She wants a loan to buy teaching materials such as white boards, markers, chairs and tables for a course she teaches. She hopes to have a well-organized course where she will be able to teach the students in a calm environment. She is very happy about Kiva in Afghanistan. Thanks from AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: She wants to make buy teaching materials like, white boards,

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida’s aspiration is to build a sustainable business to meet the needs of her family; she was thus encouraged to join KIVA partner, ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap Inc.) in the Philippines, in 1995.

The previous loans Adelaida received from ASHI were carefully invested in her sari-sari (variety) store. Since then, her business has been performing well and earning her sufficient profit. She is grateful that she has been able to educate her children using proceeds from her business as it continues to expand. She needs a loan to help enhance her business to increase her profit.

Now requesting her tenth loan, Adelaida is requesting 45,000 pesos as supplementary capital for her sari-sari (variety) store, to be used to pay for an inventory of groceries for her enterprise. Her business has been very helpful in achieving her dreams for her children. For her, it is pleasure to see achievement in her business and family; with her children growing she will want to see them having the best in life.

Adelaida is happy that her living conditions are better than in the past because she was able to generate more income from her business. She is also happy because she is able to nourish and support her husband to meet the needs of the family. She would like to send her best wishes to all her lenders around the world. She hopes that they will support her again in the future.

Adelaida’s future goals are to purchase a new tricycle (three-wheeled vehicle) for her husband to earn more income for their family. With her hard work and determination, she is hopeful that her businesses will continue to be more productive and that it will improve the overall standard of living for her whole family.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Shamen Gul Group

texts.en:
Shaperay is the group leader of Shamen Gul Group. She lives in 15th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives in a household of five members, her four children being students at secondary and high schools.

Shaperay wants to take a loan for her husband’s stationery shop business where he sells different kinds of pens and notebooks. He needs the loan to purchase more stationery, especially items which are not currently available in his shop. He hopes to expand his business as soon as possible.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her husband's stationery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of planks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Bring Ambercourt To Unite Group [Bamu], Jinja

texts.en:
Being a security guard in a Ugandan metropolis means many things. First and foremost, it means sacrificing nighttime sleep, doing without respite hours and not having enough time for family. That was the exact experience M. Dan went through before he called it quits and started his five-year-old business selling chapati (unleavened flatbread, similar to tortillas) in Amber Court Market in Jinja.

For this single 24-year-old, it was time to cast his mind to the future. Dan knew he had to extricate himself out of this problem. His decision to take up this business was based partly on the fascination Ugandans have with chapati rolled egg omelets and the fact that he needed to find a stable and more convincing livelihood. 

For the last five years, Dan has shown resilience in stemming the tide of financial and other challenges to his fledgling business that have cropped up. His hard work has been paying dividends as he has been making profits close to 30,000 shillings a week. With his determination the future looks promising.

Dan is planning on expanding his business through the purchase of more bags of chapati baking flour with the assistance of this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of baking flour to make more chapatis

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida G. is a hardworking entrepreneur who is determined to improve her family's standard of living. She joined Kiva partner ASHI in 1996 to gain access to loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.

The first few loans Zenaida received enabled her to support her family’s sewing business and their business selling curtains. The profit from these businesses has been the main source of family income. She is now requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva for the much larger amount of 45,000 PHP to purchase cotton fabrics and to support the maintenance of their sewing business. The capital will fund further expansion of the family ventures to support her dream for her children and her grandchildren to have a decent way of life.

With working capital, Zenaida’s business will keep on growing and she will be able to give pleasing service to her avid customers. Through the support of ASHI and Kiva, she hopes to see herself and her family soon improve their quality of living and move away from under the umbrella of poverty.

Zenaida hopes for an expanded business, therefore; she is requesting a loan of 45,000 pesos to pay for assorted cotton fabrics and other supplies. She requests this loan through ASHI so that she can support the expansion of her sewing business and be able to meet the growing demands of her customers.

Zenaida’s long-term goal is to have a tailoring shop a year from now so that she can give opportunity of employment to others, especially her extended relatives in her barangay (village). She hopes to maintain long-term sustainable businesses. During the course of her membership in ASHI, she has been a model member dedicated to managing her family’s operations.

loans.use: To buy assorted cotton fabrics and other supplies

loans.name: Katiereton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe 1 de l’association Katièreton sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Nimprodioula, un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution et le prêt passé a été bien  remboursé.
Les spéculations cultivées par ce groupe d’homme  sont généralement  le maïs  par LAMISSA D.. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte acheter de l’engrais et de l’herbicide. 
Les productions du groupe sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de Sikasso après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
LAMISSA  compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 100 000 par campagne qui sera utilisé pour  prendre en charge les besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Group 1 of the Katièreton association are married men who average 42 years of age and have an average of five children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Nimprodiula, one of the villages in the community of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso in order to carry out their agricultural activities during the winter as best as they can. They are on their second loan with the institution and the first was repaid on time. This group of men generally cultivate corn, and this is the case for LAMISSA D.. With this new loan he is planning to buy fertilizer and weedkiller. The group's produce is sold after the harvest in the village and at the market in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women. Lamissa expects to make an average profit of 100,000FCFA per crop which will be used to provide for the needs of the family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and weedkiller

loans.name: Kamaledine Sarbaz Group

texts.en:
Raza Gul is a member of Kamaledine Sarbaz Group. She lives in 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan, is 40, and is married with five children. She is a hardworking woman who has a quilt-sewing business. Through her income she supports her family members.

Raza Gul sews different kinds of quilt, especially the ones that she makes for Afghan brides. She hopes to progress her business and, with the loan, purchase cloth, different kinds of thread, and so on. She is thankful for Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, different kinds of thread, and so on

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Releasing merchandise at the port

loans.name: Katiereton Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe KATIERETON II sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 48 ans, 6 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Nimprodioula un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3ème région  administrative du Mali). 
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution et le prêt passé a été bien  remboursé.
Les spéculations cultivées par ce groupe d’homme  sont généralement  le maïs   par KALIFA SIBIRI D.. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte acheter des intrants ( engrais et herbicides), les petits matériels pour entretien des champs. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de Sikasso après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 KALIFA SIBIRI D.  compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 90 000 FCFA par campagne et souhaite entretenir sa collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
ll ambitionne de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The members of the group KATIERETON II are married men averaging 48 years of age and six children living for the most part in polygamous families in Nimprodioula, one of the villages of the community of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to carry out their farm work during the winter. They are on their second collaboration with the institution. The past loan has been repaid. The plantings cultivated by this group of men are generally corn, per KALIFA SIBIRI D.. With this new loan, he plans on buying some supplies (manure and herbicide) and sundry farm items for maintaining the fields. The produce is sold in the village and at the Sikasso market after the harvests. His customer base is composed of women and men. Mr. D. plans on making an average profit of 90,000 francs CFA per planting. He wishes to maintain his collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso. His ambition is to build a residential house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The cost of manure and herbicides

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita C. is thankful for the support that she got from Kiva lenders for her variety store venture in her previous loan. She prays they all be blessed. Now she is proposing another Kiva loan of 20,000 Php to continue to support the maintenance of her variety store. She has been able to improve her business due to her access to bigger loans from Kiva lenders. She is also happy because she is well able to supply and support the needs of her family. Teresita’s business has been very helpful in achieving her family dreams. Her greatest aspiration is that her children will be able to have a decent life. Her long-term goals are to help support her grandchildren's education, invest in and build a better house for the family, and to have a full-fledged mini-grocery store. Teresita now feels very happy with the service of ASHI and Kiva. It gives her family a big option to pursue their dreams. She hopes that ASHI and Kiva continue to provide the service for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead and move away from the twist of poverty.

loans.use: To continue to support the maintenance of her store

loans.name: Katiereton Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe KATIERETON III sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 49 ans, 8 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Nimprodioula un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3ème région  administrative du Mali). 
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution et le prêt passé a été bien  remboursé.
Les spéculations cultivées par ce groupe d’homme  sont généralement  le maïs  par NAMAKORO D.. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte acheter des intrants ( engrais et herbicide) et les petits matériels agricoles. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de Sikasso après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Namakoro  compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 90 000 FCFA par campagne et souhaite entretenir  sa collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Son ambition est d’acheter un vélo  pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
The members of the group KATIERETON III are married men averaging 49 years of age and eight children living for the most part in polygamous families in Nimprodioula, one of the villages of the community of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to carry out their farm work during the winter. They are on their second collaboration with the institution. The past loan has been repaid. The plantings cultivated by this group of men are generally corn, per NAMAKORO D.. With this new loan, he plans on buying some supplies (manure and herbicide) and sundry items for farming. The produce is sold in the village and at the Sikasso market after the harvests. His customer base is composed of women and men. Namakoro plans on making an average profit of 90,000 francs CFA per planting. He wishes to maintain his collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso. His ambition is to buy a bicycle for his children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying manure and hebicides

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Over the past three years, Alma R. has provided for her family by operating a sari-sari (variety) store. The profit from this business has been the main source of family income. Now she has access to working capital, her income is better than before. Alma is requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva for a much larger amount of 20,000 PHP to purchase foodstuffs for her store. This will allow her to grow the business further so that she will be able to support the education of her three children through college. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her income will steadily improve her financial stability and give her family a better life. Alma’s biggest dream is to manage a full-fledged mini-grocery store. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of her sari-sari (variety) store is one of the best ways to help provide for her family.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs of her store.

loans.name: Deomedes

texts.en:
A committed member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines since 2008, Deomedes has been a model member attending regular weekly meetings and repaying previous loans. Building her sari-sari (variety) store, Deomedes would like a loan of 20,000PHP to increase her store's inventory of goods. She is planning to purchase additional products such as rice, charcoal, and other foods for her store. Deomedes believes that offering a wider collection of goods will increase traffic and build customer loyalty in her community.

Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the productivity of her sari-sari (variety) store, and start a savings account for her grandchildren to support their studies through college. Through hard work, Deomedes is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives and support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

Deomedes is married with three-adult children. She has run a sari-sari store for more than two years. Her husband, Franklino, is an electrician.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as rice and charcoal for her store.

loans.name: Nissondiya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Nissondiya sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages polygames avec en moyenne 46 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans un  chef lieu de commune rurale, Konodimini dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage dans le village. 
Les membres du groupe vendent du riz, du haricot, des spaghettis, de la crème à peau,   des parfums etc. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire la clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elles collaborent avec  Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8ème cycle de prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Madame Mariam Traoré qui est un des membres du groupe compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 douzaines de parfums et 20 tubes de crèmes à peau. 
Elle est très sollicitée pour la qualité de ses parfums et crèmes vendus dans le village et ses environnants. 
Elle se ravitaille à Bamako en gros et revend en détail, à domicile, à la foire du village et dans les villages environnants, à une clientèle mixte, au comptant et parfois à crédit. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour l’épargne et faire l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Nissondiya are married women mostly in polygamous households who average 46 years of age and three children each all living in the seat of the rural community of Konodimini in the Ségou region (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members know one another through ties of kinship and marriage in the village.  And they sell rice, beans, spaghetti, skin cream, perfumes, etc.  With the goal of increasing their working capital in order to satisfy their burgeoning customer base, the group members are collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their eighth solidarity loan cycle.  All the preceding loans have been repaid properly. Ms. Mariam Traoré, who is a member of the group, plans on using her loan to buy five dozen perfumes and twenty tubes of skin cream.  She is in high demand for the quality of her perfumes and creams sold in and around the village.  She gets her supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali) wholesale and sells them retail out of her home, at the village fair, and in surrounding villages.  Accepting cash and sometimes credit, she sells to a mixed customer base.  She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA that will be put into savings and used to raise small ruminants.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying some cosmetics

loans.name: Patient Group

texts.en:
Abdul T. (pictured on the right) is the leader of this group. He was born in Matotoka village which is about eight miles away from Magburaka town. Abdul is 30-year-old. He is single and has no children. Abdul sells cassette tapes, tape recorders, radios, torch-light/push lights, batteries, etc. He has been running this business for many years. With his share of the loan (1,200,000 leones), he will expand his business by buying the above mentioned items.

In the picture are members of the Patient Group and loan officer, Mohmaed L. Tarawalie, handing over the loan. They are small scale businessmen in Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, seeking a loan of 1,200,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy cassette tapes, tape recorders, radios, torch-light/push lights, batteries, etc.

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Tièssiri sont des femmes mariées dans des foyers monogames avec en moyenne 37 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Konodimini : chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
C’est à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté que les membres du groupe se sont connus dans le village. 
Ce groupe fait l’achat vente de céréales telles l’arachide et le riz avec Awa Cissé (calebasse en main).
 C’est dans le but de promouvoir leurs activités génératrices de revenus, que les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur 1ier cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 4 sacs de riz et 10 sacs de gousses d’arachide. 
Elles se ravitaillent en arachide dans la foire du village et en riz petit à petit dans les villages voisins comme Somonodougouni et N’Gara. 
La vente se fait en détail, à domicile et au marché du village à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant et parfois à crédit. 
Awa Cissé qui envisage acheter 2 sacs de riz compte réaliser 20.000FCFA par mois tandis que les autres espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour l’épargne et assurer les dépenses courantes de la famille
Les membres du groupe  ont pour  ambition de faire  l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The four member of the group Tièssiri are married women in polygamous households who average 37 years of age and four children each all living in Konodimini, the seat of a rural community in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members know one another through ties of community and kinship in the village.  This group buys and sells grains, such as peanuts and rice, as does Awa Cissé (with the calabash in her hand).  With the goal of advancing their revenue-generating businesses, the group members decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan cycle.  They plan on using this loan to buy four sacks of rice and ten sacks of peanuts.  They stock up on peanuts at the village fair, and the rice is gotten a little at a time in neighboring villages, like Somonodougouni and N’Gara. Sales are made retail out of the home and at the village market.  Cash and sometimes credit is accepted from a customer base composed of women and men.  Awa Cissé, who envisions buying two sacks of rice, plans on making 20,000 francs CFA per month, while the others hope to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs that will be used for savings and for ensuring that typical family expenses are covered.  The group members have the ambition of raising small ruminants.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying rice

loans.name: Groupe 1 De Nissondiya

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe 1 de l’association Nissondiya de Daoulabougou sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de Daoulabougou dans la commune rurale de Konodimini dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des relations de parenté et de mariage dans ce même village. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs productions en culture d’arachide (telle Mama C.) et de mil, elles ont décidé d’intégrer Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1ier  cycle de prêt de campagne.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 2 tonnes d’engrais, 800kg de semences d’arachide et recruter de la main d’œuvre masculine pour effectuer le labour. 
Elles se ravitaillent en intrants agricoles à  Konodimini auprès des grossistes.
Tandis qu’elles espèrent avoir 30 tonnes d’arachide et 6 tonnes de mil, Mama C. la présidente du groupe espère obtenir 5 tonnes d’arachide dans son exploitation. 
Une partie de la production est auto consommée et le reste est destiné à la vente pour payer la scolarité des enfants et prendre en charge certains besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the 1st group of the Association Nissondiya of Daoulabougou are married women, mostly in polygamous families. On average, they are 42 years old with 3 children. They live in the village of Daoulabougou, in the rural commune Konodimini, in the Ségou region (Mali’s 4th Administrative Region.) They became acquainted with one another through marriage and because they are all from the same village. Like Mama C., the president of the group, the women decided to join Soro Yiriwaso in order to augment the productivity of their peanut and millet farms. This is their first loan cycle. They plan to use the proceeds to purchase 2 tons of fertilizer and 800 kilograms of seeds, and to hire men to do the manual labor.They purchase their soil amendments from wholesalers in Konodimini. Altogether, they expect to raise 30 tons of peanuts and 6 tons of millet. Mama Coulibably, group president, expects her farm to produce 5 tons of peanuts. Part of the production will be for their families’ consumption, and the rest will be sold to pay for children’s schooling and to help with household expenses.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pay hired laborers

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children and sells ceramic dishes. She lives in Morshin, Western Ukraine -- a popular tourist destination. Many tourists who come to Western Ukraine purchase ethnic souvenirs and decorative dishware which is why Irina’s business is flourishing. She owns two small vending locations: one in her home town of Morshin, another one in the neighboring town of Stryi. Irina offers a nice variety of items for sale at reasonable prices. She has been in the trade for four years. 

Irina is requesting a loan of 9,000 Grivnyas to increase her turnover capital for the summer vacation season when the usual flood of tourists is expected in Western Ukraine. She wants to stock her inventory with competitively priced, quality souvenirs and promotional ceramic items and is hoping to generate a good income and further expand her business.

loans.use: to increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Rahat's Group

texts.en:
Rahat Z. is the leader of this group. She is 36 and her husband works at the asphalt factory. They have a daughter, who is six and studies at school. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 12000 soms (around $260), Rahat bought a cow and started to breed cattle. She also sells milk to make some money. In this way Rahat earns 3600 soms (around $78) per month. With money received from this loan Rahat wants to purchase building materials to construct a shed for her cattle. In the future she plans to increase the amount of cattle she owns and improve her family's living conditions.

Maratbek K., 38, is married. He has two sons, the older one studies at school and the second son is too small, so Maratbek’s wife stays at home and cares for him. In order to make money Maratbek works as a welder. He has been prodiving this service for 10 years and makes 6000 soms (around $130) per month. He needs a loan to purchase building materials to repair his house.

Syndat A., 28, is also married. She has two sons, the older son studies at school and the second son is too small, so Syndat stays at home to take care of him. Syndat and her husband have been breeding cattle and selling milk for 10 years. They started with an initial investment of 700 soms (around $15) and now they earn 7000 soms (around $152) per month. With money received from this loan Syndat wants to purchase a cow in order to increase the profits received from selling milk.

Eliza Z., 26, is the treasurer of the group. She is married and has two sons. Eliza and her husband cultivate strawberries and sell their crop. They have been doing this for two years and now they earn 7800 soms (around $169) per month. Eliza wants a loan to purchase building materials to construct a shed. In the future, she plans to purchase a car and more livestock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase building materials and livestock.

loans.name: Groupe 2 De Nissondiya

texts.fr:
Le  groupe 2 de l’association Nissondiya de Daoulabougou est composé de huit  femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames et ayant en moyenne 32 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de Daoulabougou dans la commune rurale de Konodimini dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des relations de parenté et de mariage. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter la production de leurs parcelles de culture d’arachide et de mil, elles ont adhéré au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, une tonne de complexe céréales, 300kg de semences d’arachide et recruter de la main d’œuvre masculine pour effectuer le labour.  
Elles se ravitaillent  généralement en intrants agricoles au marché de  Konodimini. 
Nagnini D. qui est la présidente du groupe fait exclusivement de l’arachide sur sa parcelle.
Tandis que le groupe compte récolter 20 tonnes d’arachide et 4 tonnes de mil, Nagnini seule espère sur 3 tonnes d’arachide. 
Une partie de la production est auto-consommée et le reste sera vendu pour pouvoir assurer les soins de santé des membres du foyer et l’éducation des enfants à l’école.
texts.en:
The 8 members of the 2nd group of the Association Nissondiya of Daoulabougou are married women, mostly in polygamous families. On average, they are 32 years old with 2 children. They live in the village of Daoulabougou, in the rural commune Konodimini, in the Ségou region (Mali’s 4th Administrative Region.) They are all related by marriage. The women decided to join Soro Yiriwaso in order to augment the productivity of their parcels of land where they grow peanuts and millet. This is their first loan cycle. They plan to use the proceeds to purchase 1 ton of grain and 300 kilograms of peanut seed, and to hire men to do the manual labor. The purchase their soil amendments from wholesalers in Konodimini. Nagnini D., who is president of the group, just grows peanuts on her parcel. Altogether, they expect to raise 20 tons of peanuts and 4 tons of millet. Nagnini expects her farm to produce 3 tons of peanuts. Part of the production will be for their families’ consumption, and the rest will be sold to pay for children’s schooling and to help with the families’ health care.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pay hired laborers

loans.name: Manchester United Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Sallay B., who is pictured second from right. Sallay is age 40 and was born in Mabontor village near Magburaka. She is married with five children. Her husband is a businessman. Four of her children are attending primary school and one is in secondary school. For many years now, Sallay has been selling rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With this loan, she will expand her business by buying rice and palm oil to add to her current stock. 

In the picture are members of the "Manchester United" Group and loan officer, Mohamed L. Tarawalie, on the right, handing over the loan. They are small scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 800,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy rice and palm oil to add to her current stock

loans.name: Young Investors Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Young Investors” Group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of 800,000 leones each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Demson C. (pictured second from right) is the leader of this group. This 28-year-old is married to a student and they have one child. Demson has been a businessman for a year now; he sells spare parts. With his share of this loan, he will buy spare parts wholesale to add to his business. 

The photo shows the members of the Young Investors Group and loan officer, Mohamed L. Tarawalie, on the right, handing over the loan.

loans.use: To buy spare parts wholesale to add to his business

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with a grown daughter. She owns two vending facilities selling sportswear in one of the biggest markets in her home town of Zaporozhye. Irina offers high quality and durable inventory and has gained a good reputation among her clientele. Irina has been working in this sphere of business for 12 years. Presently, she has about 70,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her turnover capital amounts to 50,000 Grivnyas. 

Irina is seeking a loan of 9,000 Grivnyas to cover customs clearing procedure costs. She purchased trendy sportswear merchandise and was ready to introduce a new collection to potential customers, yet was faced with an unexpected rise in customs fees which caused a forced delay. Now, Irina can’t have her merchandise released until she pays mandatory customs fees. She admits she can’t handle it without additional financial assistance. Irina is planning to use profit generated from her business to buy new furniture for her house.

loans.use: To cover customs clearing procedure costs.

loans.name: Bendu Group

texts.en:
Wurie B. (second from right) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Wurie was born in Magburaka town, in Northern Sierra Leone about 40 years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and the couple have two children, both attending secondary school. For over nine years now, Wurie has been selling clothes:  T-shirts, vests, socks, etc. With the help of this loan, he will be able to expand his business, make more sales, and consequently improve his living conditions. Wurie will use his share of the loan (800,000 leones) to expand his business. He will buy T-shirts, vests and socks wholesale to add to his current ones. 

In the picture are members of the B. Group and loan officer, Mohamed L. Tarawalie, on the right, handing over the loan.

loans.use: To buy T-shirts, vests and socks wholesale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 35 year old single mother of two. She has been operating a retail shop for five years and sells spare parts and paints to earn a living. Esther was formerly employed and saved her money to start this business because her income could not support her family. She was then introduced to the Masaku Ushindi group in Faulu Kenya. This group has helped her save her money and access a loan from Faulu Kenya. Esther has requested a loan of Kes. 25,000 to add spare parts stock. She hopes to open other outlets in the future to increase her returns.

loans.use: To pruchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is married with a 7-year-old daughter. She is an entrepreneur from Energodar, which is a predominantly agricultural region of eastern Ukraine. Anna sells seeds, farming chemicals and pesticides in a little farming store and another vending location at a market. She started this venture 10 years ago. Currently, she has about 150,000 Grivnyas invested in inventory. Her working capital amounts to 50,000 Grivnyas. 

Anna is seeking a 20,000 Grivnya loan to purchase additional merchandise for this farming season. She always tries to re-stock her inventory, keeping up with the demand and varied market. Anna is very prompt with payments and hasn’t had any delinquencies with any of her previous loans. One of Anna’s long-term plans is to remodel her little store in the future.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is married with a 9-year-old daughter, called Angelina. He is a farming businessman from Dneprovka, south-eastern Ukraine. Andrei sells polyethylene film, seeds and other agricultural supplies in one of the local markets called “Stroika”. He is the only entrepreneur who offers polyethylene film for farmers in his town, which gives his business a boost every spring when greenhouse keepers come to him for supplies. 

Andrei has been in this business for 6 years. He has 80,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory and his income amounts to around 10,000 Grivnyas per month. Andrei is requesting a loan of 20,000 Grivnyas to purchase a variety of seeds and additional polyethylene film for further retail sale in his home town. He is hoping to save some of his profits and possibly buy a vehicle for his business in the future. It should also be mentioned that Andrei is an experienced farmer. He grows tomatoes on his plot of land, which helps him better understand and meet the needs of other farmers in the region.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and polyethylene film wholesale for future retail sale.

loans.name: United Traders Group

texts.en:
Marie B. (pictured second from right) is the leader of this group. Marie was born in Magburaka. She is 38 years of age, married to a teacher, and they have four children who are attending primary school. Marie sells market food such as groundnut (peanuts), rice and palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). She has been running this business for five years now. With the help of this loan, she will buy rice, groundnut and palm oil wholesale in order to expand the size and quality of her business.

In the picture are members of the "United Traders" Group and loan officer, Mohamed L. Tarawalie, on the right, handing over the loan. They are small scale businesswomen in the northern town of Magburaka. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living conditions will improve – they can at least provide three meals a day for their children, pay their school fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them falls sick.

loans.use: To buy rice, groundnut and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Famous Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Famous” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Mohamed B. (pictured second from right) is the leader of this group. The 40-year-old is married to a businesswoman and they have five children. Mohamed has been a businessman for many years now. He sells medicines. With his share of this loan, he will buy medicines at wholesale to add to his current ones. 

In the picture are members of the Famous group and loan officer Mohamed L. Tarawalie on the right, handing over the loan.

loans.use: To buy medicines at wholesale

loans.name: Raisa

texts.en:
Raisa is married with a teenage son, Nikita. She runs a public cafeteria in her home town of Mukachevo, Western Ukraine. Raisa’s pricing policy is reasonable and meals are always fresh and nutritious. She launched this enterprise only a year ago and has already invested about 100,000 Grivnyas in the business. 

Raisa is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to design and build a small children’s playground next to her cafeteria. This feature will be an additional attraction for her business, bringing in families by offering a well-equipped play area for kids. Raisa understands the responsibility and wants to make sure the playground conforms to all the required safety standards. We believe the loan will be an reasonable investment in the further development of this enterprise.

loans.use: to build children's playground next to her cafeteria

loans.name: Confidence Group

texts.en:
Shown in the photo are members of the “Confidence” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 800,000 each from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Marie F. who is pictured on the left. Marie is age 35 and was born in Magburaka. She is married with three children and her children are attending schools – one in primary school and two in secondary school. Her husband is a businessman.

For nine years now, Marie has sold market food such as onions, pepper, groundnuts (peanuts), etc. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying wholesale more of the above mentioned items.

loans.use: To buy more onions, pepper, groundnuts, etc., to sell

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en: Alfred is a 27 year-old single man. For the past four years, he has been selling and repairing watches to earn a living.  His shop is very busy during the weekends because many people get time on such days to repair their watches  Being an entrepreneur, he has learned the art of saving his money and investing in his business so he joined a group called "Yes we Can" in Faulu, Kenya where he saves his money on a weekly basis. He has requested a loan of Kes. 24, 000 to add to his stock of watches and watch spare parts. Alfred describes himself as honest and God-fearing.

loans.use: To buy watches and watch spare parts

loans.name: Lucas

texts.en: Lucas is 28 years old, married to a business lady and they are blessed with two children. For eleven years, he has been repairing bicycles and motorbikes. He was previously selling cereals to earn a living. He uses part of his income to pay wages to his two employees. He is a member of "Winners Kitengela" group in Faulu, Kenya, whose members guarantee each others' loans. Through the group, Lucas has requested a loan of Kes. 20, 000 to buy spare parts. He hopes to move into better business premises where he can get more customers. In ten years, he wants to open up another business and buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is a 25-year-old married woman with one child. She runs the Glory to God shop where she sells cereals. Her business has been running for only one year. Joyce belongs to the Mlachake group in Faulu, Kenya, and the group's members guarantee each other's loans. With her first loan of KES 20,000, Joyce plans to buy more cereals for sale.  She hopes to expand the business into wholesale in the future. She dreams of becoming the main supplier of cereals in her area in ten years. She describes herself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To add to her stock of cereals

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr: Aïssatou D. est une femme de 24 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, elle est membre de Bancc Villageois depuis 2005, elle a une ancienneté de 4 ans et demi dans ledit Banc Villageois et a 09 fois de suite reçu de crédit. Elle fait de la transformation et vente de pâte d’arachide ; elle achète  des gousses d’arachide, les décortique, les grille au feu de bois et les transforme en suite en pate. Tous les mardis elle se rend au marché hebdomadaire d’un village distant d’une dizaine de kilomètres du sien pour vendre son produit. Son nouveau prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital d’investissement pour mieux mener son activité. Son objectif est de participer au bien-être familial.
texts.en:
Aïssatou D. is a 24-year-old woman who is married and the mother of two children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois since 2005. She has 4½ years of seniority in the aforementioned Banc Villageois and has received nine consecutive loans. Aïssatou makes peanut butter and sells it. She buys the peanuts, shells them, roasts them over a wood fire, and then processes them into a paste. Each Tuesday, she goes to the weekly market of a village about ten kilometers away from hers in order to sell her product. Her new loan will allow her to bolster her investment capital for running her business better. Her goal is to help improve her family's well-being.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her investment capital

loans.name: Halimatou Abibou

texts.fr: Halimatou Abibou D. est une femme de 51 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 10 enfants et tutrice de 03 autres garçons confiés par des parents. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de SINTHIANG COUNDARA dont elle est la présidente depuis son inauguration le 22 janvier 2003. Elle est restauratrice ; tous les mardis, jour de marché hebdomadaire, elle y va pour vendre son repas. Elle est également détentrice de boutique dans le village, elle y vend divers produit tels du riz, de l’huile, du sucre, des biscuits, etc. son objectif d’une part,  est de participer à la prise en charge de la famille par exemple la santé, la nourriture et la scolarité, d’autre part, augmenter son niveau d’épargne.
texts.en:
Halimatou Abibou D., 51, is married and the mother of 10 children as well as being the guardian of three other boys entrusted to her by their parents. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of SINTHIANG COUNDARA of which she is the president, since its inception on January 22, 2003. She sells cooked food; every Tuesday, the weekly marketday, she goes to the market to sell her meals. She also has a little store in the village where she sells such products as rice, oil, sugar, biscuits, etc. One of her goals is to participate in supporting the family, for example in covering healthcare, food, and school fees, and a second is to add to her savings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expanding her income-generating activities

loans.name: Tening

texts.fr: Téning W. est une femme de 38 ans, elle mariée et mère de 4 enfants en charge et aussi tutrice d’un garçon et d’une fille. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de SINTHIANG COUNDARA depuis le 22 janvier 2003 et a 14 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit et a toujours remboursé sans difficulté. Elle fait de la transformation et vente de pate d’arachide. Elle vend son produit dans les marchés hebdomadaires des villages environnants. L’objet de son prêt est de renforcer sa production pour réaliser plus bénéfices et son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille par exemple la santé, la nourriture et la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Téning W., 38, is a married mother raising four children as well as being guardian of one boy and one girl. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of SINTHIANG COUNDARA since January 22, 2003, has received 14 consecutive loans, and has always reimbursed them without difficulty. She processes and sells peanut butter. She sells her peanut butter in the surrounding weekly markets.
