loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran has been married for twenty-three years. She has been spending her life with her family in Borewala (famous for its shrines) in Pakistan for the past eight years. She has two sons and one daughter. Her elder son operates a cosmetics-selling business and the other kids attend a local school.

A very talented lady, Sugran runs her bangles-selling business, selling colorful bangles in her community. She is showing her bangles in the photo. She does this work to give her children a better education. Her husband has thirty years of experience selling wheat in the market. His earnings help them to meet their financial expenses.

Surgan has taken three loans from Asasah and has successfully repaid them. From the profit generated by these loans she bought a color television, a cycle and a motorcycle. Now she is applying for the fourth time for a loan to expand to her husband’s wheat-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat for her husband's business

loans.name: Kicwamba Tukole Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
Hardworking M. John, aged 46, started up his hardware shop business over ten years ago. His business has, for the most part, been dealing in general building merchandise. Being strategically located in Rwenshaka, Rukungiri town, he gets many customers, earning him profits of 173,000 Ugandan shillings monthly.

John’s main drawback is having a small amount of stock that cannot match the demand from his customers. With his pub and banana-sales side-businesses, however, he has managed to cut both ways in situations like the aforementioned. John started off as a farmer and he has never looked back. He has built up enough experience that things are currently playing into his hands.

With this loan, John hopes to buy more hardware stock for his business. He is looking at buying more iron sheets, nails and cement. This, he figures, will help him expand his business market and also earn more sales revenue to cater for the family requirements of his four children who are still attending school, and also enable him to progress economically.

loans.use: To purchase more hardware stock for his business

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
B. Alfred is thirty-five years old. He is a married man, blessed with one child, and is also taking care of two dependents who are going to school.

B. Alfred owns Kemko Tech phone repairs at Central Road, dealing in phone accessories, batteries and repair. He has been running the business for the last five years. He is using the loan to purchase more phone accessories such as batteries, chargers, phones, phone housings, and so forth to expand his business.

B. Alfred’s dream is to expand the scope of his business.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories such as batteries, chargers, etc.

loans.name: Chann

texts.en:
Mr. C. is a married man who has two school-aged children who depend on him. He resides with other family members in his own small family home in Siem Reap province.

C. owns a machine that he uses to mill rice belonging to farmers who bring the rice directly to his house. In addition, C. uses any bran from the process to feed a few pigs. His wife is a good housewife and also assists him in the business activity.

C. desires to accumulate more piglets for his stall by asking for a $150 loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To accumulate more piglets

loans.name: Mary

Oquaru Asibazuyo’s dreams are for her business to expand and for her to become a successful woman in whatever she is doing.

The couple is blessed with five kids, two of whom are no longer in school and  assist their father's job, while the remaining three are still going to school. This coming growing season, Nin S. needs a loan to hire a laborer to plow his farmland and buy vegetable seeds.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Choem

texts.en:
Mr. Choem C. is a 64-year-old married man and father. He has been working in the farming sector for years and earns a suitable revenue to help meet his family’s financial needs. His wife sells porridge to nearby neighbors in the morning. They each earn approximately $2 a day. The couple works together  to support their two youngest children. Two of their older children are now employed. One is a rice farmer and the other sells groceries and raises pigs. 

Choem C. is taking out his first loan to buy a motorbike that has an attached trailer to provide a taxi service to earn additional profit.

loans.name: Burombe Bakyara Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
A determined B. Robert, aged 50 years, is a diligently focused and determined man who has a dream of owning his own big shoemaking business in Rukungiri. At present, Robert runs a small business that he began fifteen years ago in Rukungiri Town selling shoes, socks and gumboots. This business earns him a profit of 400,000 shillings on a monthly basis.

The prospects of future success for this married father of seven, don't look bad given his enterprise and his milk-sales and pig-husbandry side-businesses that help him eke out more profits.

Robert began as a retailer before he, at length, decided he would have a niche in his current business. He wants to run a wholesale shoemaking business in the future and is looking at buying a shoemaking machine. This loan will, for now, help him restock his business with new shoes, shoe polish and gum boots for resale, thus enabling him to earn more sales revenue.

loans.use: To purchase new shoes, gumboots and shoe polish for his business

He looks after a total of nine people and his main business is selling maize, beans and groundnuts (peanuts). He is also farmer like his wife; they farm to earn that extra income for their family.

Gabriel, like most produce dealers in Kibaale, faces a challenge of low marketability of his products in some seasons. He would like to engage in processing agricultural produce one day. This is his first loan from HOFOKAM intended to enable him to purchase more maize, beans and groundnuts to sell.

For T. coming rainfall season, in which it is possible to cultivate crops, Mrs. Uoch T. doesn’t have capital for T. purpose of supplying her farming business. This is why she has decided to look for a $1,200 loan from Kiva. She will use this loan to hire a laborer to plow her farmland and then buy fertilizers and crop seeds to plant. She hopes T. loan will generate additional income for her.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Determined, foresighted and hardworking women are commonplace in today's Uganda. Many are basking in the glow of the emancipation that has been accorded to them by the present government. And these women are not only prospering in Kampala, but even upcountry.

N. Regina, aged 34 years, is an example. She is a happy-go-lucky single lady with one child who has relied on a produce sales business for four years to earn her livelihood. Ever since she opened up her now growing business, she has been mostly selling dry food crops like peas, beans, maize, millet and sorghum in Kabanda trading center, Mubende.

Regina’s farming background has helped her a lot, in that she can predict and know exactly the seasons when certain crops are likely to sell more or less. In that way she has minimized losses. She also had prior experience working in a hardware retail shop.

With the passage of time, Regina has reached a stage where she makes monthly profits totaling up to 200,000 shillings. This loan is to help her buy more bags of produce to sell. This will enable her to earn more revenue to cater for her family's basic needs and also to acquire a self-sustaining life.

Regina also ekes out profits from a rental business and this serves to solidify her chances of future success.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of crops like maize, millet and beans

The couple has been engaged in this business for more than 3 years now. Bienvinida will use this new loan, amounting PHP 15,000.00, to buy additional inventory for her store. Bienvinida is grateful to ASHI-KIVA partner for the good hearts for the poor, like her family. She feels that the organization really helped them attain the possibility of reaching her dreams. That is why this couple has grown to love the institution so much and all of the lenders who are sponsoring this loan.

She dreams that one day she will be able to have her own mini-groceries store in the market, instead of just in her house. She wishes to be able to make enough money to pay for the needs of her family and also she is dreaming the best of life for her family that live together.

In order to support this farm, Mrs. Ream C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase two wheels for her plowing machine and to buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline. Aside from farming she also breeds pigs and ducks, which adds to the family income. Mrs. Ream C. is widow with three children: one is seamstress in a garment factory, one is a farmer who helps with the farm, and the youngest is a student in the local school.

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely B., 58, is married to Niverio B., a driver, and they have two children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life by managing her own dried fish business. Fely has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow ten times in CCT’s Cooperative. She uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her dried fish business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 15,000 loan to be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more dried fish. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more dried fish

loans.name: Wevina's Group

Wevina C. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 58 years old and the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is C. Group.

Wevina is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Wevina has a business providing general  alteration and tailoring services. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,600 PHP a month.

In 2008, Wevina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wevina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Wevina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used for her college daughter's tuition fees and to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Wevina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Rwenshama Tukore A, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Friendly and very hardworking K. Hope, a 42 year old married woman with four children, has been running a retail shop business for over three years. Her thriving business caters to the interests of local customers along the Congo border in Rwebinyonyi trading centre, Rukungiri.

Hope has been earning profits amounting to 150,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis. Her main challenge has been, however, having a small amount of stock due to the hindrance of low capital input in her business. Her recourse has, however, been her teaching job salary and also her small fish-selling business.

With Hope’s sense of determination, the sky seems to be the limit in her drive to establish a firm foothold in this retail business and also in her fledgling fish-selling business. This loan will help her to buy more retail items like sugar and soap as well as more fish to match the increasing demand of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more retail merchandise like sugar and soap plus more fish to sell

loans.name: Dalguillanet

texts.es:
Con $500.000 COP que le regaló su esposo en el año 1990, antes de la separación,  Dalguillanet Q., puso en marcha su primera idea de negocio que consistía en vender calzado por encargo a compañeros de trabajo de él y a sus vecinos; gradualmente fue agregando otras mercancías como ropa y luego artículos domésticos de madera, como camas, juegos de comedor y esto es justamente su dedicaciòn actual. Así fuè como  ella y con la ayuda de un crédito con el ICFES , entidad estatal de apoyo a estudiantes,  dos de sus hijos, hoy son profesionales de la medicina y la psicología y en la actualidad  ayudan a su hermana, ya casada, para que termine su carrera de enfermería.
En la actualidad Dalguillanet vive sola  y adicional a su negocio  recibe pensionadas ingresos que la abastecen, además de la ayuda de su hija médico. Este es su segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización que la ha ayudado en la diversificación de sus mercancías, especialmente lo relacionado con muebles que tienen un costo superior al de la ropa y sin el crédito no hubiera podido responder a clientes de este tipo de productos. Ahora su solicitud de financiamiento es por valor de $ 1.300.000 COP, con los que comprará ropa y muebles como camas, escaparates entre otros. A futuro piensa continuar con sus dos negocios y comprar un gran congelador para también vender pescado, porque aspira a tener  una rotación diaria de efectivo  y seguir incrementando su capital. Su desafíos ocurren cuando nuevos clientes le salen un poco difíciles con el pago y se retrasan mucho; Con esto ha aprendido y tiene mucho cuidado al dejarle su mercancía a crédito a esa clase de personas, que no la ayudan para nada a que progrese su negocio.
texts.en:
With $500.000 COP that was given to her by her husband before their separation in 1990, Dalguillanet Q. started her first business selling shoes to her husband's colleages and to her neighbors. Gradually, she began adding clothing, beds, dining sets, and other items to her stock. With the help of a loan through ICFS, a state entity that supports students, two of her children are professionals in the fields of medicine and psychology. And today they help their married sister finish her nursing studies. Currently, Dalguillan lives by herself and in addition to her business earnings she receives a pension as well as help from her daughter, a doctor. This is her second loan with the "Fundación Mario Santo Domingo", organization that has helped her expand her stock, especially in terms of furniture which is more expensive than clothing. Without the loan she would not have been able to serve customers of these types of products. Now she is asking for $ 1.300.000 COP that she will use to buy clothing and furniture as she would like to increase the steadiness of her cash flow and keep increasing her capital. Her challenges are dealing with clients that have difficulties with payments and are late. She has learned from these challenges and is very careful when giving credit to this kind of people who don't help her get ahead with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Rocio Vargas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and furniture

Mrs. Saim B. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide and to pay for a laborer to plow her farm. Her husband, Mr. Sann Seng, is a bicycle and motorcycle repairer, who earns a small income to support his family. This couple has five children: one is a beautician, two are laborers in Phnom Penh, and the youngest one is a student in the local school. Mrs. Saim B.' husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and to pay for a laborer to plow her farm

loans.name: Chhom

texts.en: Mrs. S., born in 1975 and a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, currently works as a seamstress in a garment factory. She has a life partner in her husband (shown in the photo above), a requirement laborer hired by people to do a variety of jobs. The couple now lives with their young child who is enrolled in the public primary school. Because their current income is not adequate to serve them, Mrs. S. has requested a loan to be used as capital to provide a small loan with a specific schedule repayment to a garment worker, thereby providing her with extra income.

loans.use: To provide a small loan with a specific schedule repayment.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: He is young, energetic and full of hope for success in the business world. He is Francis, a 24-year-old man living in Hoima, Uganda. He is married with two children and heads a family of four people, which he sustains with the income from his retail shop where he sells sugar, soap, salt and rice, among other things. He has operated the retail shop for two years now. Francis achieved the feat of his shop when he sold his season's harvest of tobacco. He dreams of owning a wholesale shop one day. With the loan funds, he intends to purchase sugar, rice, salt and soap to sell in his shop.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, salt, and soap to sell

loans.name: Sokha's Group

texts.en:
Six people make up a group loan located in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. Each member will use a small portion of the loan for a different purpose, in order to improve their business in the future.

Mrs. Sokha L., 40 years old, is the group leader selected by the other members in this group. She is a noodle seller in the local village, where she earns some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Saroeurn Khat, is a duck breeder and a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. Mrs. Sokha L.'s husband has a problem with his field having lots of mice and being infertile. To improve production, Mrs. Sokha L. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and plastic to protect the rice from the mice. She is the mother of three children; one attends the local public school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and plastic to protect the rice from the mice

loans.name: Noun

texts.en: Mrs. Noun N., 38 years old, lives in Rung village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Voeung Vong, are farmers who own 3 hectares of land to cultivate rice to support their family. Mrs. Noun N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine, fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for a laborer to plow her farm. Mrs. Noun N. and her husband are also farm laborers, so they can earn a small salary to support their family. This couple has three children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: to buy a water machine, fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for a laborer to plow her farm

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en:
Barbara P. is from the village of D'Ban. She is 50 years old, married and has two adult children. To make a living, Barbara owns & operates a business selling assorted vegetables. Barbara has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Barbara joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Barbara has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional stock. Barbara is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Barbara from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for vegetable vending

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn P. is from the village of Ramon Magsaysay, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 33 years old and married with no children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a general store. The other source of income for the family comes primarily from the income of her husband as a machine operator. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for eight years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
       
About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
 
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy products to sell.

location.town: Ramon Magsaysay, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Enriquita

texts.en:
Enriquita B. is from the village of Caputol. She is 37 years old. Enriquita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Enriquita owns & operates a beauty parlor providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Enriquita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Enriquita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Enriquita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Enriquita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Enriquita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her husband's motorcycle amortization. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Nansalmaa

texts.en: Nansalmaa is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house, in a yard that belongs to her sister. Her husband, Bukhchuluun, is working as an engineer. She operates a trading business at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Mongolia. Her children help her in the business. She has been operating her business since 1999, and has steadily expanded her business since then. She operates a retail business and purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. Her product selection is very good and she has a great business mind. Since she founded her business, her living conditions have improved. Nansalmaa has good communication skills and her business is very important to her. She says, “I have been planning to build a warehouse for my business and my family in the future".  She is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Gelane Musico Group

texts.en:
Gelane M. is from the village of Senor, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Gelane is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Gelane is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gelane owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gelane has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Gelane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gelane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gelane is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Gelane from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn O. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 36 years old. Arlyn is married with two school-aged children and one infant. To make a living, Arlyn owns & operates a business providing transportation services to local community members. Arlyn has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Arlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Arlyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used for house repair. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Arlyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth G. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 35 years old. Maribeth is married. To make a living, Maribeth owns & operates a business selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Maribeth has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Maribeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Maribeth is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her sari-sari business. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Maribeth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari business

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza O. is from the village of Caluya. She is 50 years old, married and has five adult children. To make a living, Liza owns & operates a business selling of own-made "nipa" native roofs. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Liza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase to pawned a parcel of nipa plantation. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Liza from PMPC.
 
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pawned a parcel of nipa plantation

loans.name: Tres

texts.en: Mrs. A. has been selling various types of fish at the market for years. She typically generates an income of $5 per day. She has been married for a long time and has five kids. One of her children is now married and the remaining four are single. Most of them are employed and contribute a small income to the family. A.’ husband also earns an income, driving a taxi for profit. Recently, her husband has not been able to earn as much income as before because his motor taxi breaks down often and it is impossible to use. A., therefore, decided to request a Kiva loan of US $1,000 to be used to renovate the broken motor taxi.

loans.use: To repair a broken motor taxi.

loans.name: Alicia's Group

texts.en:
Alicia M. is from the village of Manawan. She is 49 years old. Alicia is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Alicia is married. To make a living, Alicia owns a fishing business and it is operated by her neighbors. The main source of income for the family comes primarily from the income of her husband, a provincial employee. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2008, Alicia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Alicia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her  family.
 
About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment

location.town: Manawan, Jose Dalman, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Mr. Luk Long Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Luk L. is the village bank president, selected by the 10 members in this group located in Lieb village in Takeo province. All the members will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in the future. Mr. Luk L. is 42 years old. He is a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. He is a pig breeder, too. Now he has a problem because his pigs are too small to sell. So Mr. Luk L. is applying for a loan to buy pig food. He is a widower with five children. Two of the children are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others attend the local public school. Mrs. Nat Nget is a group guarantor so she is presented in the photo too.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony is a 24-year-old man married to a businesswoman and together they have one child. Like his wife, Anthony is also a businessman who deals in selling shoes, mostly second hand shoes, in Hoima, Uganda, a business he has done for the last five years. Like many youth in Hoima, Anthony got the initial capital for his shoe business after selling a season's harvest of tobacco, the major cash crop in the area. He says though, he would like to sell all kinds of shoes in terms of class and standard. This is his first loan from HOFOKAM and Anthony is going to purchase shoes for reselling.

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used colthing

loans.name: Serwaah Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Esther is a women’s leader, hard-working and a resourceful mother of five children. She is 53 years old and still married to a blacksmith. She lives together with her family in a town close to Sunyani. Esther is a petty trader who sells fresh yams and cooking oil to customers in her community. Operating her business for the past 24 years, Esther has amassed good marketing experience and made many repeat customers.  She plans to invest the loan to purchase fresh yams and oil to meet her customers’ demand. She dreams of being able to put up a house from her savings to improve her family’s accommodation in her home town.

Esther is currently the leader of a trust bank group called 'S.', named after Esther, made up of ten members. The other members are also engaged in food processing and petty trading businesses.

loans.use: To purchase fresh yams and cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong T. N. was born in 1979. She lives in Kim Tien village, Dong Anh town. She is a farmer who not only grows rice, but also breeds pigs and poultry. She is married with one child. Her husband is a contractor. 

She has participated in SEDA, a Kiva partner, since 2004. Her loans, which were used largely to buy food for pigs, are always repaid punctually. She is the group leader. In the next loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy six piglets and to improve the piggery. Hopefully, that plan will turn a profit so that her family may afford to buy more household appliances.

loans.use: To buy six piglets and to improve the piggery

loans.name: Pha's Group

texts.en: This group loan has five people who live Chrouy Poun village in Takeo province. They will each use a piece of the loan for different purposes to improve their living conditions. Mrs. Pha U. is the group leader who has been selected by the other members. She is 39 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Cham Roeun Sem, are farmers who own a 1.3-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. Their problem is that it is time to plant the field but they do not have money to support it. So to improve production, Mrs. Pha U. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed and rent a machine to plow the rice field. She is a mother of three children. Two of the children attend the local public school and the other helps with the farming.

loans.use: To buy seed and rent a plow machine

loans.name: Rwenshama Tukore B, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Operating a grocery business has really transformed his life. Having been prevailed upon by his wife, M. Richard began his business three years ago in Rwenshama, Rukungiri. He has mostly been selling sugarcane, sweet bananas, charcoal, tomatoes and onions. This business has been bringing him earnings amounting to 100,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis.

Being a married father of six lively children made this 44-year-old come to terms with the fact that he needed to work extra hard to improve his family's welfare. With his cultivated hard-work ethic, he has been able to cater for his family's requirements, including meeting the school fees for his children’s education. That has all been made possible with finances from his business.

Before he began this business, Richard was more inclined to farming. He still derives side profits from his small scale coffee-sales business.

This loan will enable Richard to expand his business through the purchase of more crops like sweet bananas, thus increasing his supplying capacity to his increasing clientele. This will enable him to earn more revenue and live a more sustaining life as he looks at business expansion in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase more crops like sweet bananas, tomatoes and sugarcane for his store

loans.name: William

texts.en: William is a 42 year old man living in Hoima, Uganda. He is married with four children and looks after a family with six people. William runs a retail shop and has been in the business for seven years now and he says he has no major hardships in doing retailing. Before the retail business, William was a fish monger like most people in his village since they are near Lake Albert. William is also a farmer; he aims at getting food for family to eat in his subsistence mode of agriculture. This is William’s first loan cycle at HOFOKAM and he intends to purchase sugar, salt, soap and domestic items for selling in his shop.

loans.use: purchasing sugar, salt, rice, soap for reselling in his shop.

loans.name: Yan's Group

texts.en: Four people who are villagers in Kou Duol village in Takeo province make up this group loan. Mrs. Yan S. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose. She is a pig breeder and she owns a general store at her home where she can earn some money to support her family. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Yan S. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries to sell. Her husband, Mr. Moun Chea, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare of land to cultivate rice to support his family. This couple does not have a child.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Saidu

texts.en:
Saidu K. started trading in phone accessories in the township of Makeni with a very small amount of capital, which he accessed from the sale of his father's land. He is married with four kids, all of whom are attending school. His spouse is a secondary school leaver (graduate) and now a trader. 

Saidu K. has been in business for 25 years now.  He is seeking a loan to purchase more stock and generate more income. He hopes, however, to use the proceeds from the loan to educate his children and send them abroad.

loans.use: To buy phone accessories

loans.name: Khuyen

texts.en: Khuyên Thị Nguyễn was born in 1976 and lives in Kim Tien village, which is part of Dong Anh town. She makes a living by growing rice and raising pigs. Khuyen has a daughter who is going to school, and her husband works as a contractor. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She is applying for her first loan from SEDA, which she will use to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.use: to breed the pigs and poultry.

loans.name: Mr. Chhen Nhaet Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has 12 people who live in Thnal Louk village in TaK. province. Mr. Chhen N. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. Each member will use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose. He is 59 years old. He is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Now his problem is that his field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mr. Chhen N. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer. His wife, Mrs. Butha Sam, is a congee seller at her local village. He is a father of two children. One of the children is a laborer in a mill and the other attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en: Five people in Doung Khpos village in Takeo make up this group loan. Mrs. Srey P. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose. She is 46 years old. She is a weaver at her home where she can earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Srey P. is applying for a loan to buy more silk. Her husband, Mr. Sarou Sok, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Through this activity, they support five children. One child is a weaver, one is a car repairer, and the others are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Lien

texts.en: Lien T. P. was born in 1967, has two children (a son and a daughter), and works with her husband on a farm. They have a monthly income of about 4,500,000 Vietnamdong (VND). Lien is applying for her first loan, which she will use to raise livestock. She is very committed to making repayments in a punctual manner.

loans.use: to raise livestock

loans.name: Vannak's Group

texts.en: Five people make up a group loan in Doung Khpos village in Takeo province. All the members have selected Mrs. Vannak K. as the group leader. She was born in 1977. Her position is a farmer. She owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Srun Soa, is a government worker. Although they try to work hard, they can't earn enough income. So to improve their family living conditions, Mrs. Vannak K. is applying for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food to start a new business breeding pigs. She is a mother of five children. Three of the children are enrolled in the local public school. The others are too small to work or study. The day of the loan disbursement, Mrs. Vannak K. was busy working in the field. Instead, her husband, Mr. Srun Soan, received the loan for her. The photo above is of Mrs. Vannak K.'s husband.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
K. Stephen, aged 38 years, has a family of six children. He has been operating a retail shop in Omwirwaniraniro trading center, Rukungiri, for over seven years. He has, for the most part, been trading in a variety of products for domestic use like sugar, soap, salt and cooking oil. His wife, has been at his beck and call all this while as he beat all odds to gradually establish himself.

With savings from his much older farming business, Stephen made up his mind to start this retail business. He has never lived to regret his decision as his profits have been increasing every passing month. At present, he makes 400,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. And with confidence, he says his hard work is a trump card to earning more money in the future.

Stephen’s main drawback in the course of operating has, however, been that he has been limited in terms of the variety of products he sells. He is therefore looking at increasing the array of stock for his business when he gets this loan and is also looking at expanding into a wholesale enterprise.

Stephen wants to purchase more general merchandise like maize flour, beans, salt, sugar, etc. This, he envisions, will help him earn more revenue and thereby lay a firm foundation for future success.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like maize flour, beans, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Epifania B., 60, is committed to making sure that her family has enough provisions to meet their daily needs and can live a better life. For the last several years, she has made a living by managing her own computer shop.

Epifania has been a member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She attends weekly fellowship meetings and pays   dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to take out several loans from CCT’s Cooperative. She is able to pay her bills on time because she has made good use of these loans to expand her business.     

To ensure continued growth of her small company, she has applied for a loan for PHP 20,000. She will use the money to buy new equipment and do needed repairs. She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful, and prays for good health so that she can enjoy many more years with her family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy new equipment and make need repairs to a computer shop

loans.name: Afi Epouse Gbenyo

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce dans la restauration, en 2002 elle a ouvert son propre restaurant qu’elle a appelé « TERMINALIA », les entrants dans son activité de restauration sont épuisés raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  8 sacs de maïs, des tas de tubercules d’ignames  et divers.
texts.en:
This woman is in the catering business. In 2002 she opened her own restaurant that she called “Terminalia”. She has run out of the ingredients she uses in her catering activities. For this reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES for the purchase of 8 bags of corn, piles of yam tubers and various other things.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, yams and others

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna R., 37, is committed to making sure that her family has enough provisions to meet their daily needs, and devotes a major portion of every day to ensuring that she earns enough money to give her six children a better life.  For the last several years, she has made a living as a garbage collector.

Myrna has been a member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends meetings and pays dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to take out several loans from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is able to repay her loans on time because she has made good use of these loans to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the continued success of her small company, she has applied for a new loan, for PHP 23,000. She will use this money to buy a new sidecar and repair her old one. She will also buy a new wooden cart.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy new equipment and repair existing equipment

loans.name: Wilfreda

texts.en:
Wilfreda G., 52, is committed to ensuring that her family has enough provisions to meet its daily needs. She and her husband, Eduardo G., are blessed with three children. Eduardo works as a driver, and Wilfreda helps him in his work while also running a small store as a way to ensure that they make enough money to give their family a better life. 

Wlfreda has been a member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She attends weekly fellowship meetings and pays her dues consistently. Because of her good repayment record with previous loans, she has been able to take out quite a few loans from CCT’s Cooperative.  She has used the money to expand and improve her business, and has a solid record of paying bills on time.     

To ensure the success of her small company, she is applying for a loan for PHP 14,000. She will use this loan to continue to expand her business, and to buy more items to sell to her customers.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy her own house and land in a prominent and comfortable subdivision.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Talata

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère de 2 enfants, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, elle fait ce commerce depuis 15 mois, la demande actuelle de ses clients est très élevée,  pour gonfler son stock et satisfaire ses clients elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat d’une vingtaine de pagnes de différentes qualités.
texts.en:
This lady is married and mother to two children. She has an income-generating activity trading in "pagnes" (colourful West African pieces of fabric). She has been carrying out this activity for 15 months and the current demand from her customers is very high. In order to boost her stock and satisfy her customers she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 20 "pagnes" of various quality.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma M., 55, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Herminio M., a taxi driver, she is blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been overseeing operations of their taxi for a few years now.

Norma has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), a Kiva partner, for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 20,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy equipment and spare parts for the taxi. She will be buying a new air conditioning system and a spare tire for the taxi.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can have a new business in the form of her own variety store right inside her house.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: She will be buying a new air conditioning system and a spare tire for the taxi

loans.name: Tamguila

texts.fr: Cette femme est une jeune femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants, en 2007, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de charbons de bois, plus tard elle a associé à ce commerce la vente de céréales. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays. Elle veut rehausser son stock de marchandises qui est réduit raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  5 sacs de maïs et 7 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This young lady is married and mother to two children. In 2007 she set up an activity selling charcoal, and since then she has combined this with the sale of cereals. She gets her supplies inland. She wants to boost her stock of good which has fallen, and for this reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES for the purchase of five sacks of corn and seven sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn and charcoal

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Bonifacia A., 65, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so her brood of five can have a better life.  She has been managing her own dried fish business for quite some time now.

Bonifacia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her dried fish business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities and kinds of dried fish and other dried seafood that she will be selling.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow, enough for her to be self-sufficient, self-sustaining and to be able to finally stop borrowing money.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and kinds of dried fish

loans.name: Felicity Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Felicity is a lovely and hard-working woman. She is married to a commercial driver and together they have three children. She is now thirty-three years old. Felicity lives together with her family in a rented apartment at Sunyani, where she also has her business. She is able to provide support to her family’s financial needs through the sale of “banku”. Banku is one of the Ghanaian favorite local dishes that are rich in carbohydrates. It is prepared with corn dough and some amount of cassava dough, cooked between 1-2 hours and eaten with either palm nut or peanut soup. It can also be enjoyed with ground pepper and tomatoes and tilapia. Banku is known throughout all the tribes in Ghana and commonly sold in street stalls. 

Selling for the past 15 years, Felicity has made quite a number of faithful customers through good customer relations. She plans to invest the loan to purchase maize, meat, groundnuts and other food ingredients to improve her food quality.

Felicity is currently the leader of a trust bank group called 'Felicity', named after the leader and made up of nine members. The other members are also engaged in petty trading and food processing businesses.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Marifel

texts.en:
Marifel G., 39, has been managing her own tailoring shop for quite some time now. She is married to Jemmy G., a tailor, and they are blessed with three children. Marifel is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Marifel has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her tailoring business.

 To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 16,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital to expand her business by buying materials needed to continue operations of the tailoring shop. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy materials needed for a tailoring shop

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena L., 35, has been managing her own variety store and loading station for quite some time now. She is married to Orlando L., a factory worker, and they are blessed with a child in their marriage. She is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Rowena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, Rowena would like to apply for a 20,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy groceries to replenish her current product inventory. She will also invest some of the loan amount in the purchase of cellular phone load for different networks. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries and cellular phone load for different networks

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida S., 31, has been managing her own junk shop for quite some time now. She is married to Liberato S. Jr. and they are blessed with six children. She is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Loida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow 11 times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her junk shop.

To ensure the success of her business, Loida would like to apply for a 10,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital to buy junk from collectors and sell it to bigger foundries. Loida dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She hopes that her family will continue to grow in God’s love.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy junk from collectors to sell to bigger foundries

loans.name: Odo Nyame Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Hannah describes herself as an intelligent woman. She is 54 years old and is the leader of the “Odo Nyame” (translated as "God of love") borrower group. Hannah is a petty trader who has been selling foodstuffs like yams, maize and coconuts for the past 20 years. She is excited to be taking out this loan, which she will use to purchase yams, bags of maize, and baskets of coconuts in bulk. She dreams of being able to supply yams and maize to restaurant operators. She is married to a cobbler and together they have four children from age 22-42 years. Hannah also hopes to adequately support her last born who is currently pursuing nursing education.

The other members are also engaged in trades such as food selling or selling jewelry and slippers. Hannah says her group members are co-operative.

loans.use: To purchase yams, maize, and coconuts in bulk

loans.name: Self Help Plumkor Group

texts.en:
Ndorbor K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Self Help Plumkor". He is 57 years old, married and has six children who range in age from 19 to 27 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties. All of his children are in school and he also cares for three siblings.

For 30 years, Ndorbor K. has been making and selling furniture in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 30,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 106,000 LRD group loan to buy more wood and make more furniture. His dream is to expand his business and, in the future, to be able to export timber to America.

loans.use: To buy more wood and make more furniture

loans.name: Tamaraneh Group

texts.en:
Isatu C. (third from left) is the leader of this group. Isatu was born in Sanda village, Northern Sierra Leone. She is approximately 45 years of age, married to a businessman, and they have five children – two in secondary school, two in primary school and one in college. Isatu sells rice and palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). With the help of this loan, she will buy rice and palm oil wholesale to add to her business.

In the photo are members of the "Tamaraneh" Group and loan officer, Daniel Banya, on the left, handing over the loan. They are small scale businesspeople in the northern city of Makeni. They have applied for a loan from SMT, a partner of Kiva.org. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses and make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living conditions will improve: they will at least be able to provide three meals a day for their children, pay their school fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them falls sick.

loans.use: To buy rice and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Three Sisters Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Marie F., who is pictured second from the left. Marie is age 35. She was born in Makeni and lives in Makeni with her husband and four children. Her husband is a medical doctor and her children are attending school – three in secondary school and one in primary school. For three years now, Marie has been selling cloth, clothes, chains, etc. With her share of this loan, she will invest in her business by buying the above items wholesale to add to her business.

In the photo are members of the "Three Sisters" Group and loan officer, Daniel Banya, on the right, handing over the loan. They are small scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy cloth, clothes, chains, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Fet For Shameness Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “Fet For Shameness” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Manty K. (who is pictured in the middle) is the leader of this group. The 29-year-old is married to a businessman and they have two children. For many years now, Manty  has been selling women’s dresses, shoes, and soap. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current ones. 

(In the photo are members of the 'Fet for Shameness' group and loan officer Daniel Banya on the right, handing over the loan.)

loans.use: Buy women’s dresses, shoes, and soap for resale

loans.name: Bibi Saheba Maqboola Group

texts.en:
Fraidoon, the son of M. M., is the 30-year-old leader of the Bibi Saheba Maqboola group. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan and is married with four children. He is a butcher and all the family members benefit from the income he generates. He has been involved in his butcher shop for more than 11 years. He works hard and wakes up early in the morning to sell more and to have a high monthly income. 

Fraidoon would like to expand his business and make his shop larger. He is grateful to the lenders who provide the opportunity for entrepreneurs to support themselves and their families through this process.

loans.use: to expand his business and make his shop larger

loans.name: Hamsatou

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce dans la restauration ; elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé et fait ce commerce depuis 2005, voulant gonfler son stock pour mieux servir ses clients, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat  de 10 sacs de riz, 3 cartons de spaghetti et 5 bidons d’huile. Elle est mariée avec 5 personnes à charge
texts.en:
This lady works in the restaurant business. She gets her supplies at the big market of Lomé and has been in this business since 2005. Wanting to expand her inventory to serve her customers better, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy ten sacks of rice, three boxes of spaghetti, and five containers of oil. She is married and has five people to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Malalai Hangama Group

texts.en:
Malalai, the daughter of M. S., is the leader of the Malalai Hangama group. She lives in the 12th District in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives in a family of three members. She is a good tailor and all the family members benefit from the income she generates. Malalai has 6 years of experience in this business and she is confident that she can work harder.

Malalai has requested a loan to expand her business and buy two new sewing machines. She hopes to increase her business as soon as possible and bring in some new changes. She wants to say that Kiva is a really effective loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: to expand her business and buy two new sewing machines

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est lancée en 1995 dans le commerce de céréales, ce commerce marche bien pour elle car elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de kovié, naopé et tsévié où les sacs de céréales sont moins coûteux. La demande de sa clientèle ses derniers temps est élevée raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 8 sacs de maïs, 3  sacs de farine et divers.
texts.en:
This is a woman who embarked on a business involving grains in 1995. It is going well because she gets her supplies from the country's interior in the cities of Kovié, Naopé, and Tsévié where sacks of grain are less costly. Lately, the customer demand has been high. This is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy eight sacks of corn, three sacks of flour, and various other items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Tonkolili Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Tonkolili” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Isatu S..  Isatu is about 38 years of age and she was born in Magburaka, northern Sierra Leone. She is married with four children. Her husband is a farmer and her children are attending school – two in secondary school and two in primary school.  For many years now, Isatu has been selling market food – rice, palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onion, fish, pepper, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy rice, palm oil, Maggi cubes, onion, fish, pepper, etc.

loans.name: Massanvi

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de  détail de parasol, les revendeuses au grand marché constituent une grande partie de sa clientèle car elle utilise les parasols pour se protéger des rayons du soleil en période de chaleur. Elle veut se réapprovisionner pour mieux vendre raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 20 parasols. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants.
texts.en:
This is a lady who has a revenue-generating retail business involving parasols. The retailers at the big market constitute the bulk of her customer base because parasols are used for protection against the sun's rays during hot spells. She wants to stock up again to sell more. This is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 parasols. She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying parasols

loans.name: Baroat

texts.en:
D. Baroat is a married woman with three children. She started her business as the result of economic pressure. Her husband's salary was not enough to meet their family expenses, so Baroat began to investigate what work she could do. About 4 years ago, one of her friends recommended that she sell women’s clothing, so she decided to try it. Little by little she brought in more clients, which increased her income, since her commissions increased as she sold more clothing. Baroat is applying for a loan of $1500 USD to buy merchandise and fill existing client orders. She hopes that you will collaborate with her. Along with her family, Baroat thanks you for supporting them and helping the family move ahead.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to increase working capital with the purpose of developing the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of motorbike

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en:
Shuhrat is a 23-year-old businessman. Since he was young, he has had a passion for technology and computers. Shuhrat trained as much as he could and, with a lot of effort, finished his education. Two years ago, he started a small Internet café. It offers services such as renting computers, making international and domestic calls, and photocopying. Shuhrat is at his store every day of the week as he is in charge of the business.

Right now, the Internet café needs an expansion in order to offer fax and scanner services and a small bookstore where the customers, mainly high school and college students, can meet when they need to. Shuhrat is requesting a loan to be able to purchase the necessary equipment and materials to offer his customers these services that are so much in demand. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase a new modern computer

loans.name: Blessed Group

texts.en:
Betty T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Blessed. She is 44 years old, married and has one child who is 18 years old. She was only able to attend school through 9th grade. For two years, she has been selling rice, beans, sugar and flour at the VOA Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers are attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner.

She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more rice, beans, sugar and flour. She describes herself as a quiet person. Her goal is to expand her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future

loans.use: To buy more rice, beans, sugar and flour

loans.name: Zebo

texts.en:
U. Zebo is an enterprising woman with a big desire to improve her family's quality of life. She is married with 3 children. Fourteen years ago, she started offering her services as a seamstress to her neighbors and acquaintances. Zebo began this business because she did not have a job and she needed to find an activity to support her husband with family expenses. Zebo works in a tailoring shop where she produces national dresses for women.

Zebo needs to continue expanding her business so that her children can continue with their education. She is asking for a loan of $800 USD to buy supplies to increase her production and cover her customers' demands.
